params.text: Probabilistic finality describes the finality of a transaction dependent on how probable reverting a block is, i.e. the probability of removing a transaction. The more blocks come after the block containing a specific transaction, the less probable a transaction may be reverted, as longest or heaviest chain rules apply in the case of forks.

Absolute finality is a trait of protocols based on Proof-of-Stake (PoS). Finality comes as soon as a transaction and block are verified. There are no scenarios in which a transaction could be revoked after it has been finalized.
